front.title: Proof of Process Appraisal: Forensic Assessment, Forgery Bounds, and Absence Proofs

abstract.t: This document defines the appraisal procedures for Proof of Process (PoP) evidence. It specifies the forensic assessment mechanisms that evaluate behavioral authenticity, establishes quantified forgery cost bounds, and defines absence proof constructions.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: The Proof of Process protocol (draft-condrey-rats-pop-protocol) defines how Attesters collect and seal behavioral evidence during content creation. This companion document specifies how Verifiers appraise that evidence to produce Attestation Results.

section.title: Conventions and Definitions
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "NOT RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in BCP 14 when, and only when, they appear in all capitals, as shown here.

section.title: Verification Protocol
section.t: The Verifier MUST execute the following five-step verification procedure on each evidence chain:

section.title: Step 1: Chain Integrity
section.t: The Verifier validates that each evidence packet's prev-hash field matches the SHA-256 hash of the preceding packet. Any break in the chain indicates tampering or data loss. The COSE_Sign1 signature on each packet MUST be verified against the Attester's public key.

section.title: Step 2: Temporal Ordering
section.t: Timestamps MUST be monotonically increasing. The elapsed time between consecutive packets MUST be consistent with the SWF difficulty parameter (within 10% tolerance). For T3/T4 evidence, hardware-anchored timestamps are cross-validated.

section.title: Step 3: Entropy Assessment
section.t: The Verifier computes Shannon entropy over the timing distributions in each evidence window. Minimum thresholds are tier-dependent: T1 requires 2.0 bits/sample, T2 requires 3.0, T3 requires 3.5, and T4 requires 4.0.

section.title: Step 4: Entanglement HMAC Verification
section.t: The jitter seal in each packet is verified by reconstructing the HMAC from the timing vector, SWF difficulty parameter, and session nonce. This confirms that the behavioral data was captured by the claimed device.

section.title: Step 5: State Matching
section.t: The final evidence packet's content-hash is compared against the published document's hash. Additionally, the Verifier checks that the content-hash progression across the chain is consistent with incremental editing (not bulk replacement).

section.title: Forensic Assessment
section.t: Beyond the five-step verification, the forensic assessment evaluates deeper behavioral characteristics.

section.title: Signal-to-Noise Ratio
section.t: The SNR measures the proportion of productive editing activity versus noise. Human authorship typically exhibits SNR between 0.3 and 0.7. Values above 0.9 suggest automated input; values below 0.1 suggest an idle session with injected events.

section.title: Compositional Lyapunov Coefficient
section.t: The CLC with Incremental Kolmogorov Information (IKI) measures how writing complexity evolves over time. Human authorship shows characteristic CLC patterns: initial rapid composition followed by refinement phases. A monotonically increasing CLC without refinement dips suggests retyping.

section.title: Mechanical Turk Detection
section.t: This mechanism detects patterns consistent with copying AI-generated content: large paste operations followed by minimal editing, unusually consistent typing speed during insertion phases, and absence of the characteristic think-type-revise cycle.

section.title: Error Topology
section.t: The error topology analyzes the graph of error and correction patterns. Human writing exhibits complex error topologies with multi-step corrections, while automated input shows simpler patterns (single backspace corrections or no errors at all).

section.title: QR Presence Challenge
section.t: For real-time verification, the Verifier MAY issue a QR presence challenge that the Attester must scan and incorporate into the current evidence window, proving physical presence at the authoring device.

section.title: Forgery Cost Bounds
section.t: The total cost of forging an evidence chain of n packets is:
C_total = C_swf + C_entropy + C_hardware
where:

section.title: Sequential Work Function Cost
section.t: C_swf >= n * t_vdf sequential computation steps. This cost is irreducible because SWF evaluation is inherently sequential. Even with sqrt(k) parallelism from k processors, the wall-clock time cannot be reduced below n * t_vdf / sqrt(k).

section.title: Behavioral Synthesis Cost
section.t: C_entropy is proportional to the number of behavioral dimensions that must be simultaneously forged. For a d-dimensional behavioral feature space, the cost scales as O(2^d) due to the need for cross-dimensional consistency.

section.title: Hardware Attestation Cost
section.t: C_hardware represents the cost of compromising the hardware attestation chain. For T1/T2 tiers, C_hardware = 0 (software-only). For T3/T4 tiers, C_hardware includes the cost of obtaining a valid TPM or Secure Enclave attestation certificate.

section.title: Absence Proof Taxonomy
section.t: Three types of absence proofs demonstrate that no valid evidence exists for a claimed authorship period:

section.title: Computationally-Bound
section.t: Demonstrates that the minimum sequential computation time for the claimed number of SWF proofs exceeds the claimed authorship window. This is the strongest form of absence proof as it relies only on mathematical bounds.

section.title: Monitoring-Dependent
section.t: A trusted monitoring service attests that no evidence was submitted during the claimed period. The service MUST provide a signed non-receipt attestation with a timestamp window.

section.title: Environmental
section.t: Environmental signals (device sensors, network telemetry, location data) demonstrate that the claimed authorship context was not present. For example, device accelerometer data showing the device was in transit contradicts a claim of stationary desktop authorship.

section.title: Tool Receipt Protocol
section.t: When AI tools are used as part of the authorship process, a tool receipt documents the AI contribution while providing evidence of human editorial oversight. The tool receipt contains:

list.t: tool-id: Identifier of the AI tool used.
invocation-window: Time range of AI tool usage.
contribution-scope: Paragraph-level attribution of AI contributions.
content-fraction: Percentage of final content attributable to AI generation.
editorial-evidence: Evidence chain segments showing human review and modification of AI-generated content.

section.title: Adversary Model
section.t: The adversary model defines four tiers of adversary capability, referencing the threat model in draft-condrey-rats-pop-protocol:

list.t: No specialized tools. Limited to retyping or simple copy-paste. Defeated by T1 evidence.
Access to scripting tools and basic automation. Defeated by T2 evidence with SWF binding.
Access to custom hardware and behavioral synthesis models. Requires T3 evidence with hardware attestation.
Unlimited resources including hardware supply chain compromise. Requires T4 evidence with continuous device attestation.

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: The appraisal mechanisms inherit the security properties of the underlying protocol. Additional considerations include verifier trust and threshold calibration.
